text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
Hislop, W.F.,
Aroloa.
To Sask. - April, 1932

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

It is difficult to answer a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another.

Some of the questions here will not apply to everyone; therefore, others may prove impossible for you to answer, consequently, please leave blank spaces, fill in answers if possible, or make up particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1874, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or copy for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Days That Yielded Western Canadian Pioneers East," is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires:
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experiences

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of the Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
My Father Brot Dominguez and Car to
Wisconsin in 83 freight cars at that time
were small they held 640 bushel each
Dressed out Nov 30th arrived at Wisconsin Apr 7th
My oldest Brother John came with him on first car
they were allowed 16 head of cattle & horses He had
2 old horses 4 Cows 3 sheep 1 little white Don
1 dog and 1 cat 11 hens and 1 Rooster also another half
household of feet farming drill set 1 sleighs
3 sheepers of my Father met him at Wisconsin they
had homesteaded at Moore Butten in 1881 they had
each a 40 acre of land they loaded up the afternoon of April 7th
started for Moore Butten the cows and ponies followed sleighs
they had unloaded in crate but she broke 1/2 mile out
of Wisconsin from then on she walked with cows
she raised 9 little pigs that summer that was our winters
great they came out tonight on way they shovelled snow
& ground them without tent the car rode in drum & farming
mill when tent set up cat would jump out and mills
tent when tent taken down in morning the cat would
jump into farming mill the 3 sheep all lives were not
in lamb I had 1 end lamb its other half were ram and ewe
but its ram died so had no ram and no sheep anywhere
within 100 miles or even in N.Y. as far as Father knew
but a family by name Warner who settled near whitewater they
Brot Car settlers off to the spring of 1884 they came from
Brussels Father's Brother sent a love visit rain lamb with
them form Father drove around the lake fall of 84 and got
the rain lamb when coming West on Freight train it
stopped 2 hrs in Chicago Father went for walk the Dog
Cows by name came with him he returned to Freight Car
in good time but our dog he anxiously watched for it
expecting the train to pull out any minute but finally
just before the train moved the dog appeared tepid then
Car and it reached Moore Butten safely
Father's first immigration was to Greenbush in 1853. They purchased land there from Mr. Wall for $400. They worked hard.

In 1862, our brother John married Elizabeth Brown. They were allowed to homestead 160 acres. He had two dogs and several sheep. They also raised chickens.

In 1873, they moved to Wisconsin. They had a total of nine children. They started off poor but they ended up rich.

They had a good life. They worked hard and saved money. They bought land and built a house.

They lived happily until John died in 1900. Elizabeth continued to work hard and raise their children.

They were a hardworking family who always looked out for each other.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: William T. Hislop

2. Your address: Arcola, Sask.

3. Date: June 4th, 1953

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Ont. Grey H. Huron Co.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Thos. Hislop Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): Apr 11th, 1883

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.: Grey H. Huron Co. Out. Bruce P.O. 1873 to 1883

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.): 10 yrs Born Feb 23rd 1873

9. What were your reasons for coming West?: Came with Father Mother Sister & Brothers

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?): Father came west in 1882 homesteaded built pole shanty and stable went east west winter sold out we all came west in '83
Hirola W.T.
Arcola.

To Sask. - April, 1883

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: William T. Hislop
2. Your address: Arcola
3. Date: March 30th, 1953
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Grey Co., Ontario
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Thomas Hislop, Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): April 11th, 1883
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.: Grey Co., Ontario, Co. Our Prarie, P.C.A.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child" if you were in your teens, etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West?: To earn a living and find better opportunities.

Sister & Brothers

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?):
    Father came west in 1883
    Homesteaded two-mile plot shortly after stable-two-acre eastward
    Winter sold out—we all came west in 1883
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   *with Mother Sister Brother and Uncle*

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   *Railroad*

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.).
   *changed cars 5 times Wingham London Chicago St Paul Winnipeg stayed in Wpg from Saturday morning to Monday morning reached Hopeville same night after dark left next morning for Moose Lake by sleigh horse team distance 65 miles reached destination 3rd night 1/2 stage in log house at Butter Creek the creek had broke transferred to wagon to cross the water was running 2 or 3 ft deep steep banks high snow melting reached shanty before dark and living on same place today*

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   *same place as today*

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   *Sp. July 30 T# 8 R# 4 W# 5 and Father's homestead filed on in 1842.*

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
   *Farming*
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Railroad

14. What incidents of the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the way? Meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

changed cars 5 times through London Ontario

St Paul Wisconsin stayed in loop from Saturday morning to Monday afternoon reached Minneapolis Saturday night after dark left for Edmonton Sunday morning after dark left for Edmonton for breakfast at 6:30am reached Calgary Tuesday morning at 9:30am another creek its creek head broken by washed away river other water was running on 3 bluffs steep slopes high river on same side today

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Same place as today

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Field on 8 R 7 W 2nd quarter homestead

17. Mention any other places you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How about you now?
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   about once a month

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date
    and place of marriage.
   Eva Kippman Dec 3/9/3 8 miles N.W. of Carlyle

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place
    to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West
    tell when they came and where they settled.
   Father, mother & Brothers/Sister Apr 11st 1883
   Moose Jaw District all lived and died here
   1 sister still living in Areola

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stand out in your
    memory which you would like to record?
   hauled our wheat and products to Moose Jaw 65 miles
   till 1891 then to Carlton 45 miles for 7 years
   3799
   alarmed from 92 to 1900 when R.R. came to Nicola
   threshing machine accident Sept 11-1914 by which
   my Brother John was killed aged 48 the feeder belt
   came off went to put it on put foot on hub of front wheel
   it slipped off put hand on separator feeder belt caught
   under grain belt wound up his arm tore arm off Died
   3 1/2 hrs later

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church,
    visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   much freighting Brother Joe made 2 trips to Moose Jaw
   with wheat season of 1884/85 took 4 days to go and come
   with horses 5 days with oxen 65 miles
   I had horses Brother Archie made many trips to Moose Jaw
   some gas with oxen loaded with wheat church was
   held in our shanty for some months summer 1883
   shanty size 14'x16' in 2 beds stone cut board bricks
   chairs 30 or 40 people came to service Mr. Leed was
   student he walked from place to place service held
   every 2 weeks presbyterian Mr. Leed afterward became
   principal of Regina Boardian School where he died many
   years ago
   and starting for mission 1881
19. How often do you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, who?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? By what means of travel?

25. What was your occupation at this time?
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1911

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   [Handwritten text not legible]

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.).

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction or your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   [Handwritten text not legible]

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   [Handwritten text not legible]

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1911

26. If you own a house before 1914, when did you buy it? Next month.

27. What was your trading center? (Name town)

28. Did you continue to make them? (Initiate any changes due to new terms appear-

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

30. Then (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly

on Saturdays?

31. Then (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogue?

What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of

your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of

purchases made by mail order since then.

32. Did you ever have a telephone and what company installed it? Still own it.

33. Were you ever forced to change your place of residence?

34. When did you come to Saskatchewan the first time? Was it with the idea of staying

permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you

make this decision?
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Some people moved away in early days reason great distance from R.R.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Some moved away few returned

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Father 1st J.P. 1883 1st postmaster of Clare 1884
1st Returning Officer Inwood Inter Cours 1884
sent Bushed to London to Colonial and Indian Exhibition
London Eng. 1886 to Bronze Medal for still have it
in my possession the first year grown in 1885
Father was a director of the first Greenfield agricultural society
formed in 1885 fair held in old Carlyle held about Oct. 1st 1887
13 miles from here

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1) & (2), (3).

Clare post office named after place in Ireland
suggested by Mr. Mortimer an early settler at meeting
held at outstanding summer of 83 shop & did not operate
till early in 84 the name Arcola was suggested
by a post Office Inspector by Mr. Ford the name
agreed by settlers was the same as another P.O. in
Western Canada so shop changed it to Arcola the hills
were called potato hills it was named by me in 1883 as it
resembled potato hills but at that time Hopewell lake
after H.J. Hopper who built shanty and wintered huts
there 1890-91 McLeary lake after Sam McLeary who built
shanty there to cut logs for house in early winter of 1893-4
Hopewell town lake after Jim Dan Hopper who built shanty
and stabling for their stock 1887
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

Some people moved away in early days.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

Some people moved away from R.R.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public offices, or have been active in any charitable clubs mention it here, giving dates whenever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were interested in politics, give details.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) name and occupation of person (2) date and reason for change. Give facts of name above in (1) and (2).

39. Did any of your ancestors serve in the military?
A short account of first meeting held at our shanty to petition for post office and recommend J. P. about 25 people gathered. It was decided to petition for J. P. to be named Clare. Hugh Hazzard and Irishmen wrote out petition. It was signed by all Diet. That was early in summer of 1883. The postmaster General recommended the P.O. It was established early in winter of 84. Thos Hielop Jr. Father was recommended for Justice of the Peace on motion of Tom Reed an Englishman born in 1804 but who settled in Outmore section when young man. His homestead was 5 miles south of here. Hazzard lived 1/2 miles West and North of here. Brother and sister fed the people that evening after meeting. Young men played catch with ball.

Capt. Mr. Pierce who promoted and established Cunningham Manor and Diet held meeting here in July of 1884 to get bonuses for building grist mill. His oldest son Duncan and R. Bird later member Moose River Trading Co. They had Democrat and 2 horses. They stayed with us overnight. Duncan and Bird slept in stable to protect team from horse thieves several of farmers of 45 bonus to mill some gave 60 15 bonus per year till paid the mill started to operate fall of 1886. The Capt. was big man near 6'5" corpulent must have weighed at least 240 lbs. Our 3 horses was stolen early in July one Sunday night in 84. Father walked to Carlyle next morning 13 miles there. J.G. Turiff a store keeper lent him horse and buckboard. He drove to junct of Missouri Creek and Souris River 30 miles to identify M.W.P. P. 6 of ours camped there 6 weeks later police brought back 3 horses. Lone police name Leagre was scouting in North Dakota South Souris River to came on 2 driving some horses 3 of them ans description of ours he took possession. Bro. then home they were ours.

W.T. Hielop
A short arc of new meeting held at our
shady to petition for poor relief and
recommend P. about 75 people attended
it was treated to petition for p.68 to Harold Clare
it was signed by all
summer of 1883 the postmaster General
recommended its P.O. it was established early in
winter of 84 when Philip Gray started to run
town road as a ditch crew. Born in 1804 but
who settled in Carne near action when young been
his house lead across similar route where he raised
lined 13 miles near and bought three brothers
Sister had six people that became after preaching
young men played catch with till

Capt. Mr. Pierce who promoted and established
Bannington Branch and Pier held meeting here
in July 8/1884 to get Bannor for building's
great Amill his older son Duncan and R. R. Reid
Water number three Bannor trading Co. play had
three nights Duncan and Bird played in plate
to protect team from horse stolen several 87
Farmers $48.00 would be paid for each 60
18 Bux per year till paid the grill estate & operate
fully 8/886 the Calvary by means near 68
Corps led around Knowles yard at least 2400
only 3 hours was stolen early ~ July one sunday
night in 84 father walked to Carlyle over morning
13 miles there. G. Swafford also helps them him
house and purchased he drove to bannor
and Bannor River 26 months later police brought back
campaigned 6 weeks later police brought back
to 3 homes slow police known because they was
acquiring in house Bob Smith Louis River to cause
on 8/886 some horses 3 yd claim and description
of ours to take possession Bro then know they were ours

W. T. Pickett
6.

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?

Indicate your preference, if any:

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they will be living, and occupations.

5 children: 9 grandchildren

Annmarie married to Mr. Smith
Glenn married to Mrs. Smith
Lillian married to Mr. Smith
Donald married to Mrs. Smith
Ellen married to Mr. Smith

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The coming of the railroad

To reach the first big change was the discovery of oil in 1879

An Account of Church & School History of
this parish in one family since 1883
the final missionary in this parish was
Presbyterian Student Rev. James Freeland from
Kinnettles. He came in May and left in October
1st Oct-1878 to 1879 he held service every 2 weeks along
the north side of Preston Road. He worked from place to
place through the parish ministering Presbyterian
church camps to Carlisle / 30 miles across the river from
here in fall of 1873 his missionary Rev. Wilson
had a wife the settlers built him a house by
Quince Hill and played 3 yrs then Rev. Powell
who started 3 yrs both married with children
and they all lived in building until Carlisle
The second presbyterians arrived 4 yrs
from P.E.I. The earner in May left Carlisle at the end of
October back held service every 3 weeks that way 1879
1878 Student Anna Jackson played for months
then returned by horseback a trip church
and I think the Home Mission saw 950 in
1879 ordained by James Brownly from Scotland to
serve in winter was held in April house church
was named in fall of 1879 699 people there
found stayed for 3 yrs then earner was called
for four months. In 1887 named Glass Pro 83
then bought and build in 1887
the first church was opened May 1887
then school was opened May 1887
each year was received from hilltop Schoolhouse
the schoolhouse needed a new roof in 1888
its final season it was for 6 months each yr 1887
year the S.S. completed a whole 6 months
1887-88 grew to 100 students for 2 months
and 3 in 1888 Rev. Godley traveled by foot east
Rev. Godley had happy and Buck Board her husband.

(Place Name)
By your signature
W.J. McKeep
An account of the church and school history of
this parish from 1879 onwards.

The first missionary in this parish was
Presbyterian Student. He came from
Glencarlin in 1879 and stayed there
for two weeks every month along
the north side of the river. He worked from place to
place the next year.

In fall of 1883 he moved to Carleton
Church and continued preaching there until
1885 when he moved to Newcomb.

The second missionary was an ordained
Presbyterian who started in 1886 and married with children.

The third missionary was a student from
P.E.I. He came in May and left in July.

On June 24th, 1887 the school opened
and I think the name was "Newcomb School."

The fourth building was opened in 1888
and closed in 1890.

and closed in 1893.
